dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beginning of winter. Dead cold fields; pine and bare woods; a highway that leads to a small town, a lake. Beautiful in a stark winter way but very cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars is dressed for church. He wears an old, hand-knitted paby blanket like a shawl. He looks out the window, watch smoke rise from the chimneys in the neighborhood. He watc the family next door--husband, wife, children--in an ordi Sunday morning routine. His breath mists the glass. His rooms are sterile: bed, computer, one bowl, one plate one cup; furniture he must have grown up with. We see a wedding picture of his parents, a wedding picture of his brother Gus and his sister-in-law Karin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the main house, KARIN, early 30's, pregnant but not showing yet, hurries across the backyard, past a big stac firewood, to the garage. She’s thrown a sweater over her bathrobe and wears slippers. She's the kind of woman who looks good in cold weather and no make-up. INT. LARS’S GARAGE APT.--WINTER--CONTINUOUS Lars opens the door. He’s awkward and nervous with her, a concerned to see her in the cold.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Karin!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I'm inviting you for breakfast. Lars puts his blanket around her shoulders, careful not t touch her.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Sorry, I’m on my way to church. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 2.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: After church, then. Come on, we haven’t seen you for so long.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: You're going to have a baby, run back in the house, what if you get sick?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Come on, please. She reaches to touch him, he takes a little step back. It subtle, practiced move, he does it unconsciously with everybody, most people don’t notice. But today she does.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, okay.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Promise. He watches her run back to the house--he wants to make su she arrives safely. The house, to Lars, seems very far aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin enters. cus (sleepy) well? Karin crawls back in bed with GUS, 40, a bigger, stronger warmer version of Lars.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: You owe me five dollars. Gus Not till he's sitting at the table.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Something's going on with him. I'm worried. Gus doesn’t pay much attention. He nuzzles her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 3.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You keep saying that. Your maternal instincts are kicking in.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: He never lets me touch him.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Well, we're not like your family.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: What does that mean? cus A million brothers and sisters fighting and hugging all the time.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: That’s the way it’s supposed to be.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He's shy, he'll grow out of it. I sure did. He pounces on her, making her laugh. They forget about La We hear church bells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small Protestant church, friendly, not forbidding. We c hear sincere, bad Protestant singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s bright inside, white walls, stained glass, full of ordinary working- and middle-class people. Behind REVEREN BOCK the choir sits, among them MARGO, same age and type LARS. She looks out and notices Lars, he doesn’t see her. usual with sermons, no one’s listening.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK
dialogues.text: Now, we have books and books and books of laws. But in all the world, there‘s really only one law. During the sermon, Lars’s POV: he looks at the cross, candles, flowers, a stained glass portrait of Mary and ba Jesus, other people‘s families, the little dramas in ever pew. His gaze pauses on Margo who is looking through her music. Next to Lars, a restless little boy drops a stuffe animal. Lars picks it up, hands it back. He and the littl boy look at each other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 4.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e@ REVEREND BOCK (CONT'D) We need never ask, “what should I do?” We need never pray, “Lord, what should I do?” Because the Lord has told us, “Love one another.” That, my friends, is the one true law. “Love one another” is God in action. The choir rises to sing badly again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People file out after the service. A brisk older lady, MR GRUNER, 60's, tries to lift an unwieldy flower arrangemen

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Need help, Mrs. Gruner?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Thank you, dear, it’s my turn to drop them off at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e Lars carries the flowers as they walk to Mrs. Gruner‘s She looks him over, approving.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: You’re a handsome fella, Lars. Where‘s your girlfriend? This is a question that causes Lars pain.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I don’t have one.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Are you gay? Wouldn't bother me. My grandson’s gay, I know all about the gays.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No, I’m not gay.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for? LARS. I don't know. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 5.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Well, don’t wait too long, it’s not good for you. She hands him a flower from the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give this to somebody nice, for a start. She drives away. Margo walks up behind LARS.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Hello, Lars. He turns and steps back.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Hello, Margo. Neither of them can think what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: See you at work tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Lars starts to walk away. Margo is disappointed. Then he turns back and thrusts the flower at her. She lights up.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Oh! Wait-- But Lars power-walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus cooks as he and Karin argue in a friendly way.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He’s 30 years old. Maybe he WANTS to be left alone.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: That‘s NOT what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Because that’s not how people are. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Through the window, we can see Lars sneak past, gradually increasing speed.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (spots him) Whoops, there he goes! He and Karin run to the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lars! Lars dashes toward his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: You promised! Lars waves and disappears inside. cus Five bucks.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Is that normal? Gus shrugs, turns back to cooking. Karin turns back to La apartment, a determined look on her face. INT. LARS’S GARAGE APT.~-WINTER--NIGHT Lars rocks in the rocker, still wearing his church clothe his bed made. It’s 4 AM. He’s been awake all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggard, Lars drives out. Karin watches him from the hous EXT. LARS’S CAR — DAY Lars drives to work through small-town landscape, winter bleak.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, INDUSTRIAL PARK
dialogues.text: Lars parks his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired Lars enters, greeted by CINDY, the curvy African- American receptionist. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 7.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Morning!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Hi, Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Party hard this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (lying) Oh, yeah. Woo. He's very aware of her curves, they make him anxious, yet can’t make himself move away from them. Cindy is fond of and likes to fix people up.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: The new girl’s cute. You and Margo, what do you think? Lars struggles to speak but can‘t, makes a few strange noises.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mystified) Lars? Mute, Lars waves and walks away. CINDY (CONT’D) Take care}!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Discouraged, Lars enters a room with three cubicles. KURT knee-jiggling co-worker, is already at his computer. Each cubicle features personal items: KURT’s is full of action figures. Margo's has plants and a teddy bear. Lars’s is s - maybe a small picture of Gus and Karin. We hear the distinctive REAL GIRL music theme.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You gotta see this!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I’m not in the mood for porn.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It's not porn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lars gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, it is, but check it out! Lars joins him reluctantly. We can’t see what’s on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh? Huh? Lars looks closer.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Inflatable?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Nope. Real. Like if she’d weigh a hundred twenty-five pounds, she weighs a hundred twenty-five pounds.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Look, you can customize everything. They have all these different heads and parts. You can design your own woman}

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Mine has the “Monique” head and the “Jennifer” boobs and the “Tracy” waist and the “Veronica” butt and the “Roxanne” legs. (man to man) Lars, she‘s anatomically correct. You can do anything with her.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Even--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt nods emphatically, Lars is repelled.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that would be like--tupperware. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 9.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: No freckles, no zits, no hair. BETTER than skin.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you’re gonna get one.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Nah, they cost six thousand bucks. I‘m wiped out from the new X-box. Enter Margo. She and Kurt have a playful, adversarial relationship.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Morning. They don’t notice her. She tries again, louder.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Morning!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Whoa! He zaps up a screensaver. Lars is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: (to Lars) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars ducks his head, acknowledging her, scoots back into cubicle. Kurt turns on his headbanger work music. Lars ju nerves raw. He has to tell Kurt this every day.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Headset!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Lars, it’s your day to get us coffee. He puts on his headset, but also watches Lars and Margo.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I was thinking, we’re the only ones from the lake, maybe we could carpool. Lars scoots out. Margo looks after him, not understanding (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 10.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is, you're too aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars is extremely frustrated by his inability to respond Margo. He mutters to himself, runs his hands through his hair, leaving it spiky and disheveled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE, a co-worker on his way out with a plate of frosted Tarts, looks at Lars.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You okay, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Sure. As soon as Steve leaves, Lars opens the refrigerator free and sticks his head in to revive himself. But when he tak his head out, he feels the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars steps out of the building and watches the winter sun It's cold. He's not wearing hat or gloves. A razor wind blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo’s car is next to Lars's car. She pretends to fumble with her keys, watching him approach. He’s troubled, remo LARS POV: He sees Margo, small and far away although she really isn’t. He stops at a distance from her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Hi. Both of them wait for the other to do something.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seeya. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 11.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Bye. They get in their cars and drive off in the same directio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars wanders aimlessly. SANDY, 30‘s, stylish, waves at hi from her dress shop, he waves back, joyless. Lars sits at mall fountain. He sees nothing but families and couples. the food court, same thing. He buys mall food but can‘t e He feels his isolation like a physical illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lars drives in from work, Karin stands in the middle o the driveway with a flashlight, flagging him down like th airport person on a runway. He slams on the brakes and ju out of his car, fearing disaster.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Are you okay? What happened? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We want you to come for dinner. Lars is immediately wary. Karin bounces a little on her t preparing to move. LARS. (lying) I can’t. I brought work home. He tries to dodge her, she blocks him.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: No, you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: If I don’t get it done, I’m in trouble. He dodges, she blocks.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We miss you.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (lying) I'll be there in a minute. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dodge, block.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, you don't! He breaks for the garage, she chases and tackles him. The struggle on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I hear my phone!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Salmon, rosemary potatoes!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I have other plans!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Broccoli and pie!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (claws at the lawn or snow) Thank you but let me go!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: No! She straddles him and holds him down. Lars goes limp. She won.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The end of the meal. Lars is distant and quiet, he’s hard eaten anything. Gus and Karin exchange looks. Hers says, “Talk to him!” His says, “What do I say?”

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (to Lars, gentle) Tf that’s all you can eat...

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Delicious. Karin begins to clear the table. Lars starts to help her, eager to escape.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Nope, my turn. You boys talk. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 13.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She leaves, giving Gus another pointed look. Gus and Lars in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (finally) She thinks you have a problem. Staying by yourself so much. LARS. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Dad was kinda like that.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not Dad! Gus is startled by his vehemence.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was more like a refrigerator than a man.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: No, he wasn’t. Lars looks at him, he concedes.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only after Mom died. I wish you could have known him before.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I wish I could have known HER. Gus is sympathetic but more occupied with his own discomf than Lars’s feelings, of which he is barely aware. He mak an offer, just short of sincere.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You know, we'd really like it if you move in. Lars shakes his head no. He knows Gus doesn't really mean

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The house is half yours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 14.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e LARS IT can't. Gus I don’t see why. Lars shrugs. They have nothing else to say to each other. They sit there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSTROM HOUSE
dialogues.text: Karin and Gus walk Lars to the door. Karin gives him tupperware.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Here are leftovers for you.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Thanks. I was wondering--my blanket?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (to Gus) It's by the-- e cvs I'll get it. | He goes. Lars is distant, preoccupied. Karin tries to converse.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful blanket. LARS. My mother made it for me before I was born.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She loved you very much. Like we do. She reaches to hug him, he steps back.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 15.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you want me to touch you?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I think you're imagining things. Gus returns and hands the blanket to Lars.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. Night. cus Night.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Night. Karin leans against Gus and he hugs her. They watch Lars across the yard to his dark apartment.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gus...

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: We talked, he’s fine. LARS POV: At his threshhold, he looks back over his shoul sees Karin and Gus in each other‘’s arms, they seem a mil miles away. He closes the door, which fills the frame and everything goes black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings, Karin opens the door, it’s FRED, the man.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Hi, Fred.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hi, Karin. Package for Lars. She signs for it.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: you can give it to me, I’11 take it back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 16.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Too heavy. I'll bring it around with a hand truck and Gus can carry it when he gets home. He unloads a coffin-like box. It’s heavy even for Fred. EXT. LARS’S GARAGE APT.-- LATER Karin unlocks Lars’s door, Gus drags the box inside. Kari carries a casserole dish. INT. LARS'’S GARAGE APT.-- CONTINUOUS Gus sets the box on the floor and stretches his back, cus Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I couldn't read the shipping label. She puts the casserole in the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: See, he’s taking an interest in things.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: He is a lot more cheerful lately.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Must be expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We'll give him a call. They leave. The box lies on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his cubicle, Lars hangs up the phone, his eyes shining

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Oh... He bursts into a flurry of activity, cleaning his workspa Margo's head pops up over one cubicle wall, Kurt’s over t other. They watch him tear out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls into the driveway as if it were a pit stop. INT. LARS’S GARAGE APT. -- MOMENTS LATER He flings open the apartment door, looks at the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brushes his teeth, combs his hair and straightens his He looks at himself critically in the mirror. Not quite right. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: He’s changed into a more casual, sporty sweater, likes it better. And he’s put on music--bachelor jazz, lots of sax has an expectant look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone knocks firmly on the back door. Gus answers, it’s Lars. He’s surprised and pleased, LARS never does this. Gus Come in, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire in the fireplace. Karin does pregnant woman yoga. Sh surprised, too. Lars is hesitant, but there’s something a little more bold about him.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I have a visitor. Gus That’s great!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: A visitor!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She's not from here.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She? Karin’s so pleased she punches Gus in the arm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 18.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I mean she’s from another country. Gus Wow, what do you know. Where‘’d you meet her?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: On the internet.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Everybody does that now.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She doesn’t speak much English. cus Oh, that’s okay. Same with guys at work. We manage.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: And she’s handicapped. This takes Gus and Karin aback, but only a little.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Well, so what? We don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: The thing is, she can’t stay with me. We're both young and single and she’s religious, it wouldn't be right. So... Gus and Karin are excited and pleased.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We'll put her in the pink room, and there are new towels. Just give me half an hour to pick up and get something in the oven.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (pleased with himself) Okey doke. Karin starts to hug him but remembers she can’t. Instead starts cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (proud, to Lars) Man, you quiet ones...  LARS by Nancy Oliver - 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Gus frozen on the living room sofa, they have washed up and changed to better clothes. Their faces are with shock.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: This is Bianca. (to someone who doesn’t speak English) ) Bianca, this is my brother Gus and my sister-in-law Karen. Lars and BIANCA, a life-size sex doll, sit across from th Bianca is a cafe au lait color with long wavy red-gold ha She wears a gold lame miniskirt, tight over-the-knee blac vinyl boots and a see-through black mesh midriff top over brief gold lame bra. Lars is oblivious to this.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's a missionary, but she’s on sabbatical to experience the world. Karin nods slowly, Gus can’t move.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's shy. Everything is so new.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (hoarse) Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Starving. We--uh-- Kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Come on, Bianca. He lifts her in his arms, awkward but confident.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, I gotcha. He carries her into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus and Karin put food on two plates and talk in intense whispers. We catch glimpses of Lars arranging Bianca in a chair. Gus is flipping.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He’s crazy!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Calm down. Calm. cus We have to put him in a hospital!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Nobody’s putting anybody anywhere. cus I can’t believe it. My little brother’s insane!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (£irm) Pull yourself together. If we show how we feel, who knows what could happen. We can do this. Honey, we can. We have to. Gus gets a grip, wipes his eyes. cus Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She’s our guest. Gus nods, he’s on board. Karin looks at the plates in her hands, shaken herself.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lars. (hands him the other plate) Bianca. She walks toward the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Karin, she can‘t eat!  LARS by Nancy Oliver - 21. e INT. DINING ROOM -- LATER Wooden but trying, Gus and Karin sit across from Lars and Bianca. Lars eats from both plates, enthusiastic, careful include Bianca in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Bianca's from the tropics. She’s half Brazilian and half Danish. That's where she gets her exotic coloring.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Ah. Gus Mm.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, her luggage was stolen. They even took her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: That's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I was wondering if you could help her out. Karin cocks her head with a strained smile, not sure what wants.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With clothes.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure we're the same--type.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Bianca doesn’t care about superficial things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Bianca sit on the bed, Karin and Gus stand looki at them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 22.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Gus had a good idea. Gus looks at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's concerned about Bianca’s health. Change of climate, travel...

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (catching on) Stress. And stuff.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I'll make an appointment with Dr. Bergen for, mm, tomorrow? Early. sus We’1ll all go. LARS. That makes sense. I'm taking off work to shop for wheelchairs. He stretches and yawns.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, we better hit the hay. (intimate) Good night, Bianca. I’m glad you're finally here. Gus looks over his shoulder helplessly at Karin as he fol Lars out. Karin looks at the doll. Bianca falls over on t bed, staring sightlessly.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps into the hall with Lars and Gus. She has to wor keep her voice steady.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Any idea how long she’1ll stay?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (brightly) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lars and Gus continue downstairs, Gus looks back at Karin wild-eyed. Karin stands alone for a moment in the hall, t girds herself to return to Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin is overcome with curiosity: she peeks under Bianca’ skirt.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Oh, my GOD. EXT. LARS’S GARAGE APT. -- LATER Lars drags the box out of his apartment, Gus stands in th yard, not knowing what to do.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Gotta put this in the recycling. Gus grabs it. Gus I’1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Gus. cus No problem. Lars goes inside. Gus attacks the box, tearing at it, loo for information. He finds the packing slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus sits at his computer. We hear REAL GIRL theme music. clicks his mouse and a 1-900 woman's voice speaks.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER
dialogues.text: Natasha escaped from Moscow where she was forced to be a stripper for the Russian Mafia. Now all she wants is a good American male to love. Gus clicks again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 24.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Samantha is a coed. Someday she’1ll be a personal fitness trainer, but now she’s taking time off school to find the perfect guy. Gus clicks again.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Midori left a high-paying job in Tokyo because she was unsatisfied as a woman. Looks don’t count, it's the inner spirit that truly excites her. Gus clicks again. COMPUTER (CONT’D) Tammy dropped out of high school to ride in the rodeo. Are you the right cowboy to tame this wild filly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca, in a flannel nightgown, lies under the covers in glow of a nightlight. INT. GUS AND KARIN’S BEDROOM -- LATER Gus and Karin lie in bed, freaked out and wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: The doctor will tell us what to do. cus She's family practice. We need a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She‘s a psychologist, too.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She says you have to be, this far North.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What will people think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 25.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We can’t worry about that. They worry. Right. They don’t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LARS'S GARAGE APT.-- LATER
dialogues.text: Under his mother’s blanket, Lars sleeps like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, Karin, Lars and Bianca drive through town to DAGMAR’ office. Gus is grim. Lars gives Bianca a tour, Karin list

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: «..and there’s the library and Town Hall. My father had his office in there. He was a--well, I don’t really know what he was. Gus? cus (through gritted teeth) Water and Power.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (caught up in the flow of conversation) My jeb’s at the School Department. I miss everybody, but there's so much to do on the house. I'll go back when the baby’s old enough and Gus gives her a look, she realizes what she’s doing and g quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Huh. Water and Power. INT. DR. DAGMAR BERGEN’S WAITING ROOM -- DAY The waiting room is packed with other townspeople: an old man, a middle-aged woman, a young mother and her toddler, couple of teenagers. Karin, Gus, Lars and Bianca, in her wheelchair, sit with them. Karin nods and smiles bravely the other people. Gus suffers. Lars offers magazines to Bianca. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 26.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Good Housekeeping? Ladies Home Journal? Reader's Digest? Everyone stares at Bianca. The toddler gurgles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Bianca sit with DAGMAR, a woman in her 60's, understated and humorous, with a carefully controlled intensity. She’s seen everything, but Lars and Bianca rea interest her. Dagmar checks the cuff on Bianca’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Well, her blood pressure’s low.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Is that serious?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Could be. We'll have to wait and see. Lars is distressed though he tries not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I knew she had health problems but...

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I want you to bring her in every week for a special treatment. will you do that?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Of course! Whatever she needs. He explains to Bianca, making sure she understands.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every week. Special treatment.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You set that up with Joanne at the desk, while I talk to Gus and Karin. I assume they’1l be involved...

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. They‘re crazy about her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver ~ 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e DAGMAR I look forward to getting to know you, Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Doc. Here we go. He accidentally drives the wheelchair into a wall.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oops. Watch your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Gus sit in front of Dagmar, arguing, with some heat.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, he belongs in a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: No! My Uncle Garth went to one of those places and never came back. e cus Karin, he needs more than we can give him.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: How do you know? We haven't given him anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (to Dagmar) Could you explain to her-~-

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (to Dagmar) Would you tell him not to--

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: If I may. Karin and Gus subside.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Has Lars been functional? Does he go to work, wash and dress himself?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: So far. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e DAGMAR Has he had any violent episodes?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Never! He's a sweetheart, he never even raises his voice. That's abnormal too, isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You gotta fix him. Can you fix him?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: There isn't a pill for lonely, Gus. This quiets both of them.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course I encourage you to get a second opinion. But I don’t believe he's psychotic or schizophrenic. I don’t think this is caused by genes er faulty wiring in the brain. sus So what the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appears to have a delusion. Gus What’s he doing with a delusion, for Christ's sake?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: That's what we have to find out. Chances are he’s been decompensating for some time. They look at her, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Losing his psychological balance. Karin and Gus look at each other, both full of guilt for noticing.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I guess we didn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Have there been changes in the family in the past year or so? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 29.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e GUS No, everything’s exactly the same, except Karin’s pregnant and Lars is nuts. Dagmar thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You know, this isn’t necessarily a bad thing. They look at her in disbelief. DAGMAR (CONT’D) What we call mental illness isn’t always just an illness. It can be a communication or a way to work something out. The delusion.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Great. When will it be over?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: When he doesn’t need it any more. @ Gus and Karin try to take it in.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: How do we help?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Go along with him.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no. cus Pretend she’s real? I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: She IS real. I mean, here she is.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I can’t stand this.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You won't be able to change his mind anyway. Bianca's in town for a reason. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a LARS by Nancy Oliver ~ 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e sus But~-

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: It’s not really a choice.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (determined, she commits) All right. Okay. Okay. We’ll come right out with it. We’ll tell the world.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Everybody’s gonna laugh at him.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) Him AND you. Gussuffers. INT. DR. BERGEN’S WAITING ROOM -- MOMENTS LATER Karin and Gus return to find the toddler in Bianca‘s lap. kid is captivated by Bianca, making kid sounds that have e everybody laughing. Lars looks at Karin and Gus with pr

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Bianca LOVES children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winter sun rises on all the small-town middle-class houses, doughnut shops, random trailers, open fields, emp roads, 24~hr gas station/convenience stores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, Karin, Lars and Bianca sit at the breakfast table. G attitude is not good. He’s unshaven and still in his paja

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to work?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I don’t feel good.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Bianca can help. She has nurse’s training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: es LARS by Nancy Oliver - 31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: cus No, she doesn’t, Lars. She’s not a person. She’s a big plastic THING.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Gus...

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (cblivious) She says that's why God made her. To help people.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (to Lars) You’1l be late.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I’ll call this afternoon. And oh-- He looks at Bianca, turns red, begins to tremble. There i something he wants to say. Karin and Gus wait, frightened he going to stroke out? Gus starts to move toward him, La blurts.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Bianca) You look pretty today! Gus slumps back down at the table and buries his head in hands.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bye, hope you feel better. He leaves, cheerful. Karin looks at Gus. He’s defensive.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Well, I had to try. Karin keeps looking at him. GUS (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We've been all wrapped up in ourselves. It’s true, we have.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: This is not my fault. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 32.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Come on, Bianca. (to Gus) ) We'll be on the phone. Karin wheels Bianca away. Gus feels angry and guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars whistles as he walks in. He is again drawn to Cindy' curves, but in a more cheerful way.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Morning, Cindy. (less of a struggle) You look pretty today.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Sunshine. She hands him an envelope, a party invitation.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Way in advance, but I get so excited. LARS. For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars enters, reading his invitation. Kurt and Margo are arguing, Kurt is very upset. Lars sets the invitation carefully in his cubicle, like an exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Where are they? I know you took ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Did not.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Did too. This is your revenge.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: The fake rat in your drawer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 33.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Oh, that.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Lars) She stole my action figures.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Your turn for coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Margo, with feeling) They are very important to me, Margo. If I don’t see them on my desk pretty damn soon, you better tell that teddy bear to watch his back! He storms out. Lars looks a question at Margo, shy but curious.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I'll return them. One at a time. She takes an action figure from her pocket and puts it in funny place on Kurt's desk and winks at Lars, who smiles. smiles back, encouraged. MARGO (CONT‘D) Are you going to Cindy’s party?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I was hoping you were. I wish you would.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Wait, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: You think it’s all right if I bring my girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh. (lying) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 34.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll probably bring somebody, too. MARGO’s disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin lunches with three friends: SANDY from the dress sh DEB who runs the daycare center, and LAUREL, the yoga teacher. She has just told them about Lars and Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: DEB
dialogues.text: You’re serious?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: But that’s fascinating!

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: When can we meet her? INT. GUS’S LUNCHROOM -- DAY A Home Depot kind of place. RUSSELL, MOOSE, and SEAN eat lunch with Gus, HECTOR and NELSON. Gus has just told them about Lars and Bianca. HECTOR, who is Hispanic, describes Bianca in Spanish and mime to a confused NELSON, who is Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (impressed) Dude!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Does she have a sister?

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: I wish I owned a woman who couldn’t talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poster board on an easel, “BIBLE STUDY CLASS." Karin an Gus have just told the Bible Study Class about Bianca and Lars. Mrs. Gruner, MR. HOFSTEDTLER, MRS. PETERSEN, MR. SH MRS. SCHINDLER and Reverend Bock, all in their 50’s and 6 and 70's, are bemused. MR. HOFSTEDTLER is a negative cont freak.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOFSTEDTLER
dialogues.text: We don’t want anything to do with her. She’s a golden calf. Remember what happened with THAT. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MR. SHAW is always anxious to do the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SHAW
dialogues.text: He’s not worshipping her, they’re just dating. MRS. SCHINDLER likes to look on the sunny side.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: She’s a missionary. That’s good, isn’t it? MRS. PETERSEN loves to disapprove.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PETERSEN
dialogues.text: I never heard of such a thing!

dialogues.speaker: MR. SHAW
dialogues.text: But if we go along, are we encouraging bad habits?

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOFSTEDTLER
dialogues.text: These young people have no will power. « Gus He's SICK.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We thought if we came to you, you could help--pave the way--a little. If you could try to understand. Please. The group mumbles, not knowing what to do. Mrs. Gruner ge impatient.

dialogues.speaker: BIBLE STUDY CLASS
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know...never thought something like this...shouldn’t expose the children...but if he needs help...belongs in a loony bin...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Oh, for heaven's sake, what’s the big deal? (to Mrs. Schindler) Sally, your cousin puts dresses on his cats. (to Mrs. Petersen) (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 36.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hazel, your nephew gave all his money to a UFO club. (to Mr. Hofstedtler) Arnie, everybody knows your first wife was a klepto.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOFSTEDTLER
dialogues.text: She wasn't!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Then how come she’s buried in a pair of my earrings?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK
dialogues.text: Now, that’s enough now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: These things happen. Lars is a good boy. You can depend on me. Gus Thank you, Mrs. Gruner.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOFSTEDTLER
dialogues.text: Well, he can't bring her to church, can he, Reverend Bock. Absolutely not. The others look at Reverend Bock.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK
dialogues.text: The question is, what would Jesus do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Gus stand in a pew next to Lars and Bianca. Bia wears a Sunday dress and has a hymnbook in her lap. Every is on their feet finishing a hymn, but Lars is the only o really singing since all the other people are staring at Bianca. When everyone sits, Margo stays standing in the choir, astonished, till somebody pulls her into her seat.

dialogues.speaker: REV. BOCK
dialogues.text: We'd like to welcome all our new members and visitors today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People file out of the church, but hang around for a clos look at Bianca. Gus and Karin wait, tense, as REV. BOCK t to Lars and Bianca. The Bible Study Class stands in a gro to the side. Mrs. Gruner holds a flower arrangement. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: by Nancy Oliver - 37.

dialogues.speaker: REV. BOCK
dialogues.text: We're happy to have you, Bianca. Come back next week, won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Oh, we will.

dialogues.speaker: REV. BOCK
dialogues.text: God bless. (to the dumbstruck couple behind them) Ted, Agnes, good to see you. The Lindstroms and Bianca proceed past the Bible Study Cl

dialogues.speaker: BIBLE STUDY CLASS
dialogues.text: (tentative) Hello, hello, good morning, nice to meet you... Mrs. Gruner places a flower arrangement in Bianca‘s lap.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: These are for you. (to LARS) She has a darling figure.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (to Bianca) This is my friend Mrs. Gruner. Karin and Gus look at each other, a little relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, Karin, Lars and Bianca go to their car. Children fol them, enchanted by the big doll. Unseeing, they pass Marg who watches them, wheels turning in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With difficulty, Karin wrestles Bianca out of church clot and into outdoorsy young matron clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Gus carry Bianca out of the house and put her in Lars’s car, now equipped with a wheelchair thing on the b and a handicapped sticker. Lars is very cheerful. Gus is worried.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Where are you going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 38.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I want to show her around the lake. She asks so many questions. She wants to know everything about me. cus Oh. That‘s nice. Have fun. As Lars gets in the driver’s side, Gus arranges Lars’s blanket carefully over Bianca’s legs and closes the passe door. Gus waves, then stands, depressed, watching as they drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Bianca drive out to the lake, the only car on a read through the winter landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in her church clothes, Margo stands on the sidewalk front of the house. After a few moments, she walks toward door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin opens the door to Margo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars tramps through the winter woods carrying Bianca slun over his shoulder like a sack of flour. He stops to catch breath and look around.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Forts all over! Leaf forts. Snow forts. So many places to hide. Tree fort--part of it’s still up there. He sets her down, compelled to climb up to the tree fort.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Bianca, watch this! He hangs upside down by his knees, trying to impress her.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me!  a LARS by Nancy Oliver - 39. e EXT. WOODS -- LATER Lars has been talking to Bianca from the treehouse for a time, a child's endless, wandering monologue.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: In the summer, Gus and I used to fish here. Even my father sometimes. And in the winter play hockey. That was so much fun. There was a big pack of little boys running around. Me and Peter and Brian and Doug and Stuey and oh, all of us. They're grown up and married now, it‘s all different, they got so far ahead, I don’t know how that happened. You can watch me chop wood, I’m really good at that... He goes on and on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus sits at his computer, heavy-hearted. He types “Mental Illness” into a search engine. He starts to concentrate, e@ studying, his interest engaged. He clicks around, seek information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo and Karin have tea and talk. They are kindred spiri instant female rapport. Karin shows Margo family pictures

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: This is their mother. And this is when Gus joined the Air Force. He was eighteen, Lars was eight. That’s their father in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: He looks so sad.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Poor Mr. Lindstrom. He did the best he could, but without his wife——

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: There’s no substitute for a woman. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 40.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e@ KARIN Gus is taking this very hard.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Who wouldn't? Karin is also taking it hard. She starts to ery. Margo tr to comfort her. She seems to know something about sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: We should have known, we should have done something sooner. What's going to become of him?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Try not to worry, it never changes anything and it won't help Lars. Tell me about the baby. Do you know if it’s a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I forgot I was pregnant. Margo, matter-of-fact, closes the photo album and hugs Ka

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: eo Karin, life goes on. In my experience, you have to find happiness wherever you are, even in the middle of desperate times. You have to fight to be happy and never give up, no matter what. Her belief in what she says gives Karin strength.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: You're right. At least Lars looks happy now.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: See? That's something. The women feel more positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, we see Lars wheel Bianca down the empty winter cemetery path. We see the simple markers for LARS’s parents: “Elinor Lindstrom 1942-1972, Beloved Wife and Mother.” “Paul e Lindstrom, 1935-1998, Beloved Husband and Father.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 41.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lars stands close to Bianca and looks at the graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca lies on the table. Dagmar looks at her, thinking. There’s a tap on the door and Lars steps in. They keep th voices low.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I_couldn‘t wait any more. Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: After the treatment, she has to rest. It doesn’t work without the resting. They watch her for a few seconds. DAGMAR (CONT’‘D) Keep me company? They tiptoe out. INT. DAGMAR’S OFFICE -~ LATER They sit together, it doesn’t feel like a therapy session all.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Bianca doesn’t deserve this, she's a good person. She’s warm and giving and loving.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Iocan see that. She doesn’t have any parents?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: They died when she was a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Oh, that‘s not fair.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: But she doesn’t feel sorry for herself. She’s determined to make the best of things. More than anything, she wants a normal life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 42.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e@ DAGMAR She has a lot of courage, I admire that. Lars looks at a framed picture of a laughing man that sit Dagmar’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Your husband?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Yes. He died.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Children?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: No. Lars touches the frame, compassionate. LARS. You must get lonely. Dagmar tells him the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars, sometimes I get so lonely I forget what day it is and how to spell my name. Lars looks at her--a connection is made.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin, Bianca, Deb, and Laurel in Sandy's shop. Sandy sho them a dramatic red dress.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: DEB
dialogues.text: Look what it does for her hair and that gorgeous complexion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy Oliver - 43.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She's half Brazilian and half Danish.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: This is a terrific dress.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She‘ll never wear it, she's too conservative.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: With that body? What a waste. They continue to look through the rack of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus in an

dialogues.speaker: LUNCHROOM
dialogues.text: intellectual discussion with Sean, Moose, Hector and Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: So what’s the difference between a delusion and a hallucination?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Hallucinations are when you see stuff that’s not there at all.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Bianca, like, is.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Not haloos.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Delusion.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: False perception versus false belief.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Okay. So when Sean thinks the FBI's after him--

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: (he can relate) DEA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 44.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (he can relate) INS.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: (he can relate) IRS. ATF. Triple A.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: That’s a delusion.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Dude, they ARE after us. The men agree. Gus Bad example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars chops firewood as Bianca watches. He works in just a shirt, sweating, concentrating, showing off, he burns off sexual energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing a window, Karin is caught by the sight of them. S notes the sexiness of Lars, which she’s never noticed bef

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unaware of his sexiness, Lars happily swings the ax.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LINDSTROM BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Gus and Karin give Bianca a bath. Bianca's hair is ina shower cap. They scrub her diligently and carefully, work as a team. cus One, two, three...

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Flip. They flip Bianca over to wash the back of her. It's hard work. They take a break, sit back. Bianca floats face dow the water. Gus looks sad. Karin pokes him with her toe.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. It’s a LITTLE funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: es LARS by Nancy Oliver - 45.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It Is a little funny. They start to laugh. Gus tosses his sponge in the air. ‘INT. DAGMAR'S OFFICE -- DAY Lars and Dagmar talk casually.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Tell me about Karin, I don’t know her very well.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Oh, she’s wonderful! Gus and I are darn lucky with women. But she-- He stops.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: We don’t have to talk. Let’s find you something to read.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Between us?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Karin has a problem.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Oh. Maybe you shouldn’t tell me.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I can’t let her hug me and she gets upset.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Angry?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: More frustrated. She’s very affectionate, she likes to touch people. But I can’t let her. Dagmar picks up some papers and looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Hm.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: It hurts. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 46.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Like a cut? Or a bruise? Lars has to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Like a burn. Like when it's fifteen below and you’ve been out in the snow for a long time and you come inside and your feet start to warm up. That kind of burn.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Happen with everybody? Lars shrugs, not wanting to admit.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not Bianca. Not so much.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: So you don’t let people touch you. Isn't that a little hard to get away with?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not here. (indicates his clothes) ) With all the layers. You know. Dagmar thinks about it a second.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You‘re right. Well, we can’t change Karin, but there is a cure for the burning. Lars is skeptical and hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Will it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR,
dialogues.text: Especially at first. Lars considers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 47.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Well, all right. For Karin’s sake. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dagmar tests Lars by touching him. She pushes him with on finger.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Nothing. She puts her hand on his arm. LARS (CONT’D) Uh...

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Hurt?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not too bad. She puts her arm around his shoulder, Lars jerks away fro her.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. Dagmar quickly moves away from him.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Okay. That’s too much.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: We'll try this. She holds his hand lightly. He winces- DAGMAR (CONT’D) It'll get easier.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (dubious ) If you say so. They hold hands. It’s a lot of work for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars wheels Bianca to the door. He’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party in progress: booze, no drugs, a little yuppie-i but good music, everybody from work is there. Fire in the fireplace. Cindy dances with her husband BAXTER. Margo st around, a little lonely, Kurt plays video games with othe knee-jigglers. There’s a knock. Cindy and Margo exchange look, they both move toward the door. Cindy opens it. CINDY’S POV: Lars looks scared and hopeful. Bianca's hand are wrapped around a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Sunshine! And is this Bianca? Welcome, welcome, come on in. Baxter, help us with the chair. Lars, this is my husband. Everyone has been briefed. They try to act normally. Ina strange way, the party starts to come alive.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Hey, Lars, how you doing. Bianca...

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (takes the wine) Is that for me, Bianca? Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I‘’1l take your coats.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (he helps Margo take off Bianca’s coat) Hi, Margo.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Hi. They smile at each other while they care for Bianca. Lars looks around: there is color, warmth, life. Kurt slaps La on the back. He is beaming. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 49.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You are a WILD man! (boast, to others standing around) I introduced them. The other people approach, cautious and curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo stands by the food table with co-workers JERRY, a j and LISA, a twit. Jerry eats constantly. They’re watching Lars and Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It’s a good thing you sent that memo. I would have FREAKED. It’s so bizARRE.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: {watching Jerry) It‘s a disorder. Like compulsive eating. It goes right over Jerry's head.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: What a weirdo.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: When you were little, didn’t you believe your toys were alive?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: That's different. They’re only alive at night when you're asleep. Lars whispers something in Bianca’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: He's creepy, he scares me.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Lars?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Look at him. He’s in love with that slutty hunk of rubber.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Her name is Bianca and you don’t even know her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 50.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Bianca? What kind of name is that?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Ethnic.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Does he have sex with her?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: That’s what she’s FOR, babe.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Ew, how CAN he?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Well, she’s prettier than a lot of people and definitely smarter.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: They should lock him up and toss the key. Jerry agrees with his mouth full.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I heard you two are getting married.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY LISA
dialogues.text: No! Yes! Jerry and Lisa turn on each other. Pleased, MARGO moves o INT. CINDY’S HOUSE: LIVING ROOM -- LATER Lars stands with a couple of guys, they talk about comput er sports. He keeps an eye on Bianca, who is off to the s Kurt talks animatedly to Bianca about himself. Lars notic Margo laughing with ERIC, who's tall, good-looking in a b Viking way. Lars doesn’t quite know how to feel about it. can’t help but appreciate Margo's curves, how attractive nice she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Bianca sit with co-worker women: Cindy, Margo, TERRI, and VICTORIA. The women are kind of drunk and talk all at once, like birds. Lars is delighted, surrounded by women, he's never had so much female attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter dances around Bianca’s wheelchair, Cindy dances enthusiastically with Lars who is so shy he just stands there, Kurt dances with Margo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars sits on the floor and watches the fire as the party on around him. He looks up at Bianca and smiles at her. H very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy and Margo wave from the open doorway as Lars and Bi drive away. Margo is wistful.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I like her, but that’s a big waste of a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: So, you and Eric, what do you think? Margo perks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Maybe. They close the door. INT. LAR‘S CAR -- LATER ‘Lars and Bianca drive home. LARS. That was the best night of my life. He bravely puts his arm around Bianca and she falls again him like a log.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus and Karin watch a movie, holding hands. Lars and Bian sit next to them, also holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt, Baxter, Lars and Bianca watch a hockey game. The gu have put all their food in her lap and her hands so they don’t have to hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in the pew behind Lars and Bianca, Mrs. Gruner le forward and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Bianca wants to spend Thursday afternoons with me.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (to Bianca) You do?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: She wants to volunteer at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (possessive) I don’t know. Her blood pressure...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Lars. Think of the little bald children. Won’t they love her! He has to admit they will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars sits with Bianca. Across the hall he sees Karin who doing something in her bedroom. He notes her swelling bel his face unreadable. INT. DAGMAR‘S OFFICE Lars and Dagmar sit next to each other, arm in arm, light

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Pain?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I can take it. We can see Lars’s need for and appreciation of female con and comfort. Dagmar decides to broach what she knows is a loaded subject. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 53.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You must be excited about a baby on the way.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. He shifts position. One of his hands grabs tight to the other.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to be an uncle?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. I think about it all the time. Dagmar watches him like a hawk. He twists his hands witho knowing it

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, Bianca can’t have children. Because of her condition.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: That's a shame. He gets up and paces.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not really. At least she’s safe. In Bianca‘s culture, there's a high rate of infant mortality. And her mother, well, when Bianca was born, her mother died right in the middle of things.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Like yours.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Strange.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You have a lot in common. He sits down with her again, agitated, wringing his hands

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: If anything goes wrong with Karin, it‘ll kill Gus. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 54.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He loves her so much. He doesn’t even know how much he loves her.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Things are different now. We've learned a lot, we haven’t lost a mother in years.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: But it could happen again, Dagmar. It could. Dagmar won't lie to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Yes. It could.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: That would be the end of everything. He’s pouring sweat.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They have no idea of the danger. No idea, Lars is finding it hard to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Put your head between your knees. He does. She rubs his back in circles, gently. He reacts pain, but lets her continue. DAGMAR (CONT’D) That’s a lot of pressure, Lars, to be the only one who knows the danger. Maybe we could talk to them about it.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No, no! What good would it do. Don't say anything. Let them be happy while they can.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: But what about you? Lars keeps his head between his knees trying to catch his breath. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 55.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I'm fine. He’s not fine.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Most of us walk around in a dream, taking everything and everyone for granted. It’s hard to be the person who knows it’s a dream. Because YOU understand we're not just talking about a baby here. We‘re talking about life and death. Lars raises his head.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see the big picture.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I wish I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I know. But somebody has to. Lars sits up a little more.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: What kind of world is it? When someone’s born someone else has to die.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: That’s what it’s all about. Everything comes and goes. Can't be summer all the time. Lars sits up more, stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: It can in the tropics.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Ask Bianca about the rainy season. Lars hasn’t thought about this.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is life, Lars. Mother Nature. She has to take her course. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 56.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's worn out, the tail end of the savage anxiety attack.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I guess... Dagmar links arms with him again.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ow. But he carefully leans his head on her shoulder, thinking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars happily wheels Bianca around the mall. Some people g them, some stare. Sandy beckons them to her dress shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca models the red dress, propped on a mannequin stand Lars looks at her proudly, outside the window with Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: How about afternoons Monday and Wednesday and then all day Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca sits in the chair as Margo, Cindy and a stylist discuss how to cut Bianca’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: STYLIST
dialogues.text: You better be sure, ‘cause it’s not growing back. INT. DEB’S HOUSE/DAYCARE CENTER - DAY Bianca sits in front of a group of rapt children, books o tape playing in her lap. In the midst of another task, De glances at Bianca, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca demonstrates a yoga pose in Laurel’s class as Laur teaches. INT. GUS’S BUSINESS -- DAY Bianca sits inside the door, holding a sign that tells wh for sale. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gus, in home-improvement conversation with an ignorant customer, looks over at her and loses his train of though She seems to be looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Gus? Gus tries to shake it off. cus Sorry. What were we--?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Drywall. Gus still feels her looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Er, drywall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Bianca have a romantic dinner with candles.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Fried walleye? He tempts her, playfully waving a loaded fork around, coaxing.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beer batter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin looks at the garage apartment, the silhouette of La and Bianca. She watches their shadows entwine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus sits in a favorite chair, staring into space. He look tired and sad. Karin enters and sits on his lap. They don speak for a few moments, communicating telepathically.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He's not going to get better.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Probably not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hug,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 58. Gus He’s a one-woman man, like my father, like me. He'll love her for life and it's all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: It isn’t. Nobody meant any harm.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I left home as fast as I could, I never thought about him. And then the two of us move back here fat and happy while he moves into the goddamn garage like the family dog. And I let him.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (thinking of her own crimes) Leftovers.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: My own brother. How could I be such a bastard? No wonder he orders a fiance in a box.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We can’t change what we did. We can only keep going and try to be good to each other.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I‘ll make it up to him. I don’t know how, but I will. Gus‘s arm around her belly. The baby kicks.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: oh! cus oh}

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Kick. Feel, Their mood lightens immediately as they concentrate on feeling the baby kick.  LARS by Nancy Oliver - 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca in attendance at a town meeting, seated between La and Mr. Hofstedtler. In front of them, a panel of citizen reports its findings. Lars is bored. MR. FOX is the unive droning bureaucrat.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FOX
dialogues.text: Pursuant to standard procedure, the Athletic Funds Allocation Committee has responded to the request of the Extracurricular Activities Panel by investigating the possibility of purchasing a new or perhaps pre- owned volleyball.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hofstedtler, I think Bianca’s bored.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOFSTEDTLER
dialogues.text: Well, she wanted to see American politics. That’s what she told me. Lars sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FOX
dialogues.text: We will now open discussion to community input regarding same. Mr. Hofstedtler leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOFSTEDTLER
dialogues.text: I’m a Republican and I object! Who's on board? He raises Bianca’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt plays with his action figures. Lars arranges picture his cubicle--candids of Bianca with other people. He noti Margo and Eric flirting in the hall. Kurt catches Lars’s points at them and makes kissing noises.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Lars, have you met Eric?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No. He joins them reluctantly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 60.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (good-natured) You’re famous around here. Margo gives Exic a warning look as Lars and Eric shake ha The strength of Lars's grasp surprises Eric.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: That’s a hell of a grip, pal.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: That's right. Lars returns to his desk, irritated, without knowing why. INT. MARGO’S CUBICLE -- LATER Margo works diligently at her computer. There is now a picture of Eric in her cubicle. Lars’‘s head pops up on t other side of the partition. He looks annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down. He is full of feelings he can’t understand identify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars enters the empty kitchen, in a bad mood but not know why. Being a guy, he expects Bianca to fix his mood.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Bianca!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: We're up here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Mrs. Gruner have just finished dressing Bianca party dress. Lars appears in the doorway. He’s miffed and sulky. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 61.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: The hospital volunteer banquet at the VFW. Doesn’t she look beautiful? Lars doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: We were supposed to play chess.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Her schedule’s on the refrigerator, did you check?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Well, they’re giving her an award, she has to be there.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Could we have a couple of minutes alone, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Mrs. Gruner listen to LARS’s muffled, semi-rais voice. Mrs. Gruner's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: They NEVER fight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: I don’t like his tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca sits in the car. Lars and Mrs. Gruner stand outsid arguing. They're both angry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Now, you listen to me. Bianca has a life of her own.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah, but-- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a LARS by Nancy Oliver - 62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e@ MRS. GRUNER No self-respecting woman is going to be at your beck and call, Mister, the sooner you learn that, the better.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: A girlfriend should--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: You’re away at your job all day, is she supposed to wait for you? Would you do that for her? Would she even ask you to?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No, but--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
