dialogues.text: Bianca’s out there contributing to others less fortunate, you should be proud of her.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She‘s always busy. What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big baby. You’re just like my husband! Mrs. Gruner gets in her car and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’1l be home at 11. LARS is very angry as Mrs. Gruner and Bianca drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars storms through the Lindstrom house stopping to yell Karin, who is doing pregnant woman yoga in the family roo

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She's my girlfriend, she can’t just go off like that! Karin falls out of her pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars paces around by the firewood, muttering to himself i little boy’s rage. Karin comes out to see what's going on She‘s surprised, he so rarely exhibits emotion.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Lars?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: What if I took off and left her alone. What if I abandoned her. How would she feel?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Stop yelling, she didn’t abandon you, she’ll be home at-- Lars doesn’t stop yelling.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: How do I know that? I don’t know that. You never know who’s coming back and who isn’t. People do whatever they want, they just go, they don’t care, they don’t think about how I feel! They don’t care about me! Karin gets mad.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Now wait just a darn minute. We do care, we all care.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No, you don’t! Nobody cares about me!

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: That is not true! Every person in this town bends over backwards to make Bianca feel at home! Why do you think she has so many places to go and so much to do?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Because--because-—

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Because of YOU, because all these people love YOU. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 64.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We push her wheelchair, we drive her to work, we drive her home, we wash her, we dress her, we carry her, we get her up, we put her to bed, and she is not petite, Lars, Bianca is a big girl! None of this is easy for any of us, but we do it, for YOU. So don't you dare tell me how we don’t care. She walks back in the house and slams the door. Lars, spe tries to figure it all out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars stands beside Bianca, who sits in her wheelchair, a plaque in her lap. Mrs. Gruner prepares to leave. Karin p out a window to watch.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Gruner. Before--I didn’t mean it. Mrs. Gruner cuts him a break.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Well, at least you're man enough to admit you’re wrong. Unlike my husband. They share a little laugh. Mrs. Gruner holds out her arms him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, come here, you big goof. Lars lets Mrs. Gruner hug him. It's work, but he does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca's in bed. Lars buttons her last button, and tucks in. Gus opens the door and is surprised to find him there cus Hey!

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: How was basketball? Gus The cheese inspectors beat the crap out of us. (confused) (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 65.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything all right? I mean, I usually put Bianca to bed.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (resolute) Not any more. That's my job now. Baths, too. Gus is slightly scandalized.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Bianca’s culture is very comfortable with nudity. I was the one who felt funny. But we‘re close enough now to-- That’s all Gus wants to hear.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Okay. Well. That's up to you. G’night.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah, you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin lies with her feet up, reading, as he enters, suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What‘d I miss?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (excited, good news) We had a big fight! cus Not

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yes! They're both delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 66. @ EXT. LANDSCAPE -— DAY It's sunny. An icicle melts, Water flows into a street dr you can hear it run through pipes under the pavement. A b sings. There’s mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars looks at Bianca. Dagmar looks at Lars, sensing somet different about him. They keep their voices low.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: My office?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I’m going to stay with her. She’s feeling pretty lousy.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: We'll both stay. She watches Lars who watches Bianca, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Last week, I asked her to marry me. e Dagmar tries not to look dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Congratulations! When's the happy day?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She said no. Dagmar knows this means something but is not sure what.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Oh, my.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it. He reaches over and takes Bianca's hand.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She said she’ll think it over. He holds her hand against his cheek. Dagmar considers thi development.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars goes to the soda machine. He secretly watches Margo Eric eating lunch together. They laugh, intimate. Lars punches the soda machine button with force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars sits in the pews by himself. Bianca, robed like the others, sits in the choir. Margo manipulates Bianca’s han make her wave at Lars, but his attention is on the minist

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK
dialogues.text: When we are children, we behave as children. But the time comes when we must surrender childish things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca sits in the sun while Karin paints a piece of baby furniture. Karin checks her work.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: What do you think? Too yellow? INT. LINDSTROM HOUSE: KITCHEN --— CONTINUOUS Gus cooks. Lars watches Karin and Bianca through the wind Something important is on his mind. Karin, with her autom thoughtfulness, adjusts Bianca's wheelchair so that the d stays in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: In Bianca‘’s culture, people have a shaman to teach them. Gus is absorbed in creating, he's not really listening. Gus Shamu? Lars talks half to himself, half to Gus.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Shaman. A wise person. There are rituals and ordeals and if you live through them, then you have new powers, and you know you're an adult and it’s time to take your place in the community. How did you know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 68.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: How did you turn into a man? Gus‘s focus remains on spices. cus Couldn’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Was it the Air Force? Should I kill something? He picks up a carving knife. This gets Gus's attention.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: No, jeez, no, put that down. Lars puts it down and looks at Gus expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gimme a minute. (can’t find the words) I never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Is it sex? cus (uncomfortable) ) Well, it’s kinda sex, but not, you know, I don’t know, it’s--well. Damn. Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I really need to know. The dryer buzzer goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus puts clothes from the washer into the dryer. Gus You should ask Dagmar.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I did. She said who’s someone you admire and I said Gus and she said ask you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 69.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: @ Gus pauses, surprised and moved. He clears his throat. starts putting dirty white things into the washer. He kic the laundry basket full of dry clothes toward Lars. cus Fold those, willya? And pass me the bleach. Lars does. GUS (CONT’D) I can only give you my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: That's all I want. He listens hard. Gus thinks, figuring it out as he talks. Gus It's not like you‘re all one thing or the other. There’s still a kid inside. But you grow up when you decide to do right. Not what’s right for you, what’s right for everybody. Even when it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like...

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Well, don’t jerk people around. Don’t cheat on your woman, take care of your family. Admit when you're wrong. Look out for poor folks and sick folks and old folks. Try, anyway. He tries to find more to say, but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh, that’s all I can think of. Sounds pretty easy, but for some reason it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) Nothing's easy. cus Like Dad. He didn’t have to raise two boys alone, he could have given us away, people do that. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 70.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he loved us and he tried to do @ right, even though he didn’t know how. Even though he had a broken heart. LARS folds laundry, quiet, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pause. Gus decides to be a man. He apologizes with difficulty. He faces the biggest failure of his life.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Lars, I shouldn’t have left you alone with him. He was too sad, it scared me and I just--I just ran. That was selfish. I should've taken better care of you. I’m so sorry. He and Lars look at each other. They both know it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (lightly) ‘S okay. It’s all over now. e GUS lightly cuffs LARS, full of relief, affection, love smiles at him. EXT. POND --— DAY Lars and Bianca sit and talk, face to face. We can’t hear what he says, but he’s intense about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca sits while Lars walks around, close to her but restless. He doesn’t talk, he’s quiet, thinking. He looks things on the ground. He looks at the buds on trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca leans against the tree trunk. LARS sits in the treehouse and looks at things from above. INT. DAGMAR’S OFFICE Lars moves around, restless, as Dagmar pretends to read a magazine. For a little bit he says nothing, then speaks abruptly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 71.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I‘m not sure the treatments are helping. Dagmar looks at him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She goes everywhere and does everything, but some days her heart’s not in it, I can tell. He sits to face Dagmar.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do YOU think they're helping? The treatments? Dagmar decides to take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I'm sorry. We knew it was a long shot. It’s the answer he expects, but it still hurts.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You tell me. Lars thinks. Dagmar waits, interested.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Is this the only chance we've got?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You could take her to the city and see different doctors who might know more.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She doesn’t want that. She loves it here. She trusts you.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: We can always keep trying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OT
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 72.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: You never know. She might turn a corner.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: She might.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She loves me. But when I say let's get married, she says no, not yet, or she doesn't say anything at all. More and more, she doesn’t say anything at all. He lowers his head, discouraged. But Dagmar watches him w a little smile, her eyes bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed, the appearance of the cubicles has chang Kurt's has a different configuration of action figures. Margo’s is rearranged, with more plants. Lars’s features Sears-like studio portrait of himself and Bianca, Lars wo as Kurt and Margo fight. Margo is very upset, she holds h teddy bear, which has a noose around its neck.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: You crossed the line!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You keep swiping my action figures!

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I hide them, I don't hang them!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You‘re too old for that thing, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Take off the noose.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Take it OFF!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Face it, Margo! That bear is dead. Hal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver ~ 73.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kurt puts on his headphones and returns to work, jiggling knees triumphantly. Margo starts to cry and runs out of t room. Lars follows her, cuffing Kurt.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Moron.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You play, you pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo sits at a table holding her strangled bear. Lars en and sits with her. Kindly, gently, he takes the bear away from her and starts to take the noose apart.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: It's not only the bear. I broke up with Bric. Lars offers insincere sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I didn’t even have a good reason. He just wasn’t very -- interesting.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Then why was he your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: (defensive) I get lonely, is that so hard to understand?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No. He returns the repaired bear to her. He almost pats her i sympathy, but can't quite manage to touch her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: What are you and Bianca doing Friday night?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: School Board meeting with Mr. Hofstedtler. (proud) Bianca got elected. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 74.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Wow! That's great. (disappointed } Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I was thinking we all could go out somewhere. She shrugs and starts to walk back to the office, blue.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (impulse) After I drop her off I'm free. Margo turns and smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo concentrates as she raises a bowling ball in front her face, then hurls it down the alley with appropriate b language. She makes a spare. Lars takes his turn, knocking three off the right. Margo cools her hand over the air vent. Lars knocks one pin off the right. He’s annoyed with himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: You're not following through.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moose, Hector, Nelson and Sean check for available lanes. They each have their own gear. Russell works behind the d spraying shoes.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Sorry, we're full up. Next week's the Ladies League Tournament. Except for Lars, the lanes are full of fiercely bowling women. The men are disappointed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 75.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Nada?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Dude.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Tell dem lady go.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: No way, Nelson, they’ll shred me.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Is that Lars? Hey, buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo and Nelson are neck and neck for the lead, then Moo Lars and Sean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all bowling together having a wonderful time. Ma watches Lars when he’s not watching her. He makes her smi and he makes her sad.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (to Margo, tesing) Mahgong, kick you butt!

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: No, Nelson, I kick YOU butt. Lars watches Margo while she’s not watching him. She make him smile and she makes him sad.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: {to Margo) Baby, where you been all my life? Moose winks at Lars as Margo laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo and Lars sit at a table behind the other bowlers, changing out of their bowling shoes. Something is on Lars mind. She looks around the bowling alley with a little bu of happiness. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 76.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: This was exactly what I needed, things look so much better. Thanks for bowling with me, Lars. She is very close and very pretty. Lars can smell her perfume.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (blurting) Don’t get the wrong idea. I'll never cheat on Bianca. Margo is shocked and appalled.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Oh, no! I would never! I hope you didn't think -- Lars, no. I can't compete with her, I'd never try.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: A man doesn’t cheat on his woman.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Absolutely. And vice versa. Besides, I don’t need to steal anybody’s boyfriend. One of these days, I’ll find a man of my own and we'll be happy, too. is not so thrilled to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yup. That‘’s the way it works.

dialogues.speaker: BOWLING ALLEY ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: and Margo stand outside. It starts to snow.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I‘d better go pick up Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Snow. watch snow fall for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I was hoping winter was over. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 77.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Only a thaw. Winter won't be over till Easter. They watch the snow fall for another moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Night. As Margo turns to leave, he suddenly pulls off his glove sticks out his bare hand at her. Margo is taken by surpri

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Ah! Lars takes a step closer, his hand still extended, as Mar realizes what he wants. She takes off her glove and they shake hands. The touch of her flesh sends an electric cur through Lars. Kurt was wrong. Nothing's better than skin. Lars’s hand buzzes with sensation. He feels it all over h body. Margo takes her hand away slowly.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Night. She walks away. Lars puts his hand to his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca‘s balanced on the edge of the tub in a towel. Lars dries her slowly, tracing the lines of her face. Then the outline of her body: her neck, her shoulder, her arm, gathering information about the female form. It’s bizarre tender, sensual and intimate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin lies down, her feet elevated into Gus’s lap where h massages them diligently. Gus stops massaging and listens cus It’s too quiet up there.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Don’t listen.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: But -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 78.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Gus, I really can‘t think about it. Gus You're right. He massages again, they both think about it, uncomfortabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dagmar takes Bianca’s blood pressure as Lars watches. She leoks at him and shakes her head slightly. Lars rubs his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green shoots in the garden. Karin, muddy, inspects carefu Bianca holds the garden tools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus and Lars paint the walls, listening to sports on the radio. They converse without much thought, if any.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: You care if it’s a boy or a girl? ous Nah.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Me, neither. cus I just want a kid. Don’t know why.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah, me, too. Gus give him a look, but Lars is happily painting. INT. LARS‘'S GARAGE APT.-- EVENING Bianca lies on Lars's sofa, as if she’s ill, in his arms. LARS blots her face with a cool cloth. He kisses her fore and looks worried and loving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars ducks in his cubicle as, on either side, Margo and K throw things at each other--balls of paper, paper clips, pens, staple removers, etc. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 79.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e LARS Cut it out! I mean it! Right now! They pay no attention to him. Cindy appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Margo, are you coming to lunch or not?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Yes! Wait for me! She grabs her purse and dashes out to Cindy, laughing as pelts her with objects.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: This place is a big kindergarten.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Margo, you loser! A few moments quiet after the big battle. Lars stretches

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think she likes me. oe LARS Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: All that girly energy? She’s ready for a man.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not you.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Like a ripe peach on the tree. Watch me pick her off. (sound effect) Thp.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not in a million years.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You'll see. Thp. Kurt jiggles his knees, cocky. This really bugs Lars who suddenly whips a ball of paper at him.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 80.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They continue the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars chops firewood with abandon as Bianca watches. Karin watches from the kitchen and calls out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Lars, we have plenty, it’s almost April. But Lars keeps chopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoughtful, Dagmar looks at Bianca on the table. INT. HALLWAY —- CONTINUOUS Lars waits nervously. JOANNE walks by him. He catches her and blurts, desperate for reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Dagmar wanted to see her alone today. Joanne, compassionate, gives him a squeeze, he accepts it

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: You hang in there, Lars. Everything's gonna be okay. He tries to smile at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dagmar holds both of Lars’s hands, which doesn’t seem to bother him at all now. She’s very serious.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Just say it.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I think you're right. Bianca’s not responding to the special treatments. It hits Lars hard. DAGMAR (CONT’D) How's she been with you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 81.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Not good. Not good. What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I don’t think there's anything we can do. (cautious) Have you thought about sending her back to the tropics? LARS. No! She doesn’t want to go, she doesn't want to leave me.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She doesn‘t ever want to leave me. Dagmar makes a move toward him to comfort, but he turns a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his way to bed, Gus shuts off the light in his office. Then the light in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the various lights go out. INT. LINDSTROM HOUSE: GUS AND KAREN’S BEDROOM -- CONTINUO From the doorway, Gus admires Karin. She’s now very pregn Feeling his gaze in her sleep, Karin wakes a little.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Come to bed?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Be right there.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: ‘S cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senselessly, but because it’s his nature -- he does this every night -- Gus opens the door to check on Bianca and, seeing her safe, closes the door quietly, so as not to wa her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars tosses and turns in bed, the baby blanket thrown off him. He’s asleep but his unconscious is working hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca lies in bed with her nightlight, serene. INT. GUS AND KARIN’S BEDROOM -~ MORNING Gus and Karin sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LARS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (panicked) Gus! Gus! Gus is out of bed in an instant, completely disoriented b ready for action. Gus Yeah! He locates the door and runs out as Karin struggles to ge up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianca lies in bed, still in her pajamas, Lars stands bes her, Gus runs in.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She won't wake up, I think she's unconscious! Gus is stumped. How do you tell if a doll is unconscious?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Wh--huh--are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yes! Gus (at a loss) Uh... Karin enters. Gus looks to her. GUS (CONT’D) Bianca’s unconscious! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 83.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Uh...call 911! Lars dashes out.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know! You always expect me to know what to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ambulance speeds through the streets, Gus and Karin fo in their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swinging doors burst open as, lying on a gurney, Bianca i rushed to a treatment room. Gus, Karin and Lars follow. N AMY stops them, compassionate.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE AMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, you’ll have to wait out here. Dr. Bergen’s on the way. Gus puts his arm around Lars’s shoulder pulls him away fr the door. Lars is distraught.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I want to be with her!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: It’s okay, it’s okay... They step away, Gus tries to talk LARS down. Karin and Am share a few private words.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE AMY
dialogues.text: She‘s Volunteer of the Year, we love her. So much nicer than a real patient. When are you due?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Three weeks. Seems like a lifetime. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (been there) Oh, I know.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I’m so excited. A baby!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE AMY
dialogues.text: Karin, there’s nothing like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two nurses put a hospital johnny on Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars sits, pale and waiting. As in the time before Bianca seems far away. Dagmar enters and sits with them. She loo serious. Karin senses bad news.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Bianca‘s very sick. @ Karin looks at Lars. She and Gus are alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: No, she isn’t. She couldn’t be. Lars?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She didn’t want to tell you. She didn‘t want you to worry. Karin is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: No. Gus How sick is very sick? Dagmar looks at Lars.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She’s dying. No one knows what to do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: by Nancy Oliver - 85.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. Oh, my God. She starts to cry. Gus is thoroughly bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: But~-

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: How long do we have?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: That’s up to her.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Does she know?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: She knows. She’s a brave girl. No one knows what to say.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll observe her till she’s stable, but she wants to go home with you tonight. They all try to absorb this. Lars stands.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Where is she? Dagmar and Lars walk away as Gus and Karin look at each other, at a total loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the door to Bianca’s room, hospital personnel and other patients peek to see Lars at Bianca’s bedside, hold her hand, his head bowed. Nurse Amy steps in, softly clos the door, and addresses the troops.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE AMY
dialogues.text: If anybody laughs or bothers that boy, you‘re on the next bus to Siberia, I kid you not. Move along. She shoos them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a different position, Lars sits next to Bianca. He loo like everyone else who waits at a hospital bed with a dyi loved one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin, Gus and Dagmar in discussion. Dagmar is excited in own calm way.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: What‘’s it going to do to him? How can we let it happen?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: We're not letting it happen, it’s Lars. It‘s always been Lars. Gus defends him.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He didn’t ask to be lonely or sick in the head.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: No, no, of course not. But do you see? He’s making the decisions. He’s the one who found her unconscious, he’s the one who said she’s terminal.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: You saw his face. Why would he put himself through this.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Partly, I think it’s your mother. I think he’s reliving the greatest loss of his life. Only he's not a helpless infant now, this time he has a chance to come through it whole.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: But that doesn’t connect. Mom’s heart stopped on the table. Lars never even knew her. Karin holds her belly, realizing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy Oliver - 87.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Oh, he knew her.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Everything connects. INT. GUS AND KAREN‘S CAR -- NIGHT Karin and Gus are quiet in front, holding hands as Gus dr home. Bianca reclines against Lars in the back.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: (tentative) Okay back there?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (distant) They gave her something. She's asleep. They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You know, anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Anything we can do. There's silence for another little while.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: We'd like to stay together in the pink room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars and Bianca, in pajamas, are asleep in bed, their arm around each other. Gus opens the door, checks on them, cl the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo's making coffee, Cindy enters, her eyes full of tea

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Cindy, what?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Baxter’s sister Candace called.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: The nurse? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a e LARS by Nancy Oliver - 88.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: It's Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy tells other people in the mall about Bianca. INT. GUS‘'S LUNCHROOM -- DAY Moose tells everybody about Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gruner tells the Bible Study Class about Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deb tells the children about Bianca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel and her yoga class meditating. Laurel hits a littl gong and speaks in her meditation voice, but she’s also emotional.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL
dialogues.text: And as we end our meditation, let's visualize Bianca and Lars surrounded in healing rays of bright white light and divine love as we pray for the best possible outcome for all beings. A few moments of meditation.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Namaste.

dialogues.speaker: CLASS
dialogues.text: Namaste. They bow to the divine in each other. Laurel hits the lit gong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It‘’s raining. EXT. LAKE —~ DAY Raindrops fall on the lake, sending ripples over the surf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answering machine blinks and blinks. The phone rings rings. INT. GUS AND KAREN’S BEDROOM —~ DAY The phone in the room is unplugged, we hear the ringing f away. Karin naps. The windows are open enough so that win makes the curtains billow, as if they’re breathing. A dre like look and feel. We can hear the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars lies in bed asleep, holding Bianca. The doorbell rin He wakes to see and hear the rain, as the doorbell sound away.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Spring. He gets out of bed. Still in his pajamas, his hair messy, leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars walks down the stairs and opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mail truck drives away, a couple of houses down. The Lindstrom porch is full of flowers, gift baskets, candles Get Well balloons. There is a bag of mail. Astonished, La walks down the steps into the rain, looking after the mai truck. He looks back at the porch, a vivid display of col on a grey day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doorbell rings. Gus opens the door to find Mrs. Gruner, M Schindler and Mrs. Petersen each bearing casseroles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars sits by the bed in his rocking chair, holding Bianca hand and rocking. There’s a soft knock on the door, enter Mrs. Gruner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Gruner.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Weak, but no pain.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Let’s bring her down to the family room.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: She wants to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Petersen and Mrs. Schindler sit with Lars and Bianca They have brought crocheting, knitting and needlepoint to

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: @ We sent Gus and Karin off to the movies.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PETERSEN
dialogues.text: They didn’t like to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: No, it‘s good they went. I feel awful about this, when the baby’s almost here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PETERSEN
dialogues.text: That’s how life is, Lars.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: Everything at once. Mrs. Gruner enters with a plate of food for Lars.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Thanks, I’m not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Well, keep it in your lap. Bianca may want to pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 91. They sit in companionable silence. Mrs. Schindler hums to herself. Lars starts to eat, first picking, then building appetite. They sit. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Is there something I’m supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: No, dear. You eat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: (placid) We came over to sit.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PETERSEN
dialogues.text: That‘'s what people do when tragedy strikes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: They come over and sit.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Don‘t you feel a little better?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same. The women crochet, knit and do needlepoint. Lars listens closely to the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Of course there’s an afterlife.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: Look at Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PETERSEN
dialogues.text: My grandfather always said, “When you're gone, you’re gone. There’s nothing but nothing.”

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Mean as a snake, that man. Famous for it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 92.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: eo MRS. PETERSEN We were so grateful when he had the heart attack and fell into a coma. Mrs. Gruner and Mrs. Schindler agree, with feeling.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRUNER
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PETERSEN
dialogues.text: Well, he was about to die. Didn't even twitch all night. Then all of a sudden he rears up in bed with his eyes wide open and he says, (joy and surprise) “Oh!” Then, clunk, he was dead. I was there, he saw something, I know it in my bones. He never looked so glad, like a boy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCHINDLER
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, that happens. e@ MRS. GRUNER No doubt in my mind. Lars looks at Bianca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking down the street from opposite directions, deep in thought, each bearing casseroles, Dagmar and Margo meet e other on the walk to the Lindstrom front door.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: oh, hello.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Hello. I’m Margo.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I’m Dagmar. They go up the walk together.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Isn't it awful about Bianca. @ Dagmar is not sure if she’s serious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dagmar is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 93.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, we all have to go sometime.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: But so young! Poor Lars. charmed by her sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Dagmar try to fit the casserole dishes into a refrigerat lurks at t All Margo’ They look eyebrows. or already filled with casserole dishes. Margo he door to the rest of the house, her mind on Lars.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Darn it. I thought about a ham.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: We have four hams. And three turkeys.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: You should freeze them, for when the baby comes.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, I think I will. s energy is directed upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: This is the part that’s so hard. The waiting. Are you sure he's all right? at Margo. Dagmar looks at Karin, raises her Karin raises her eyebrows back.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Pretty sure. But he won't leave her and he won't bring her down. It’s like that some days.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: (to Karin) Should I go up there? I trust your judgment.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: (unconsciously territorial) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 94.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l go up. Lars and I are very good friends. We went bowling.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: (amused) Then you outrank me. They both look to Karin for advice.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Honestly? I feel like he wants to be alone with her. They‘re in their own world.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: Okay. He knows what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Not many men would be so devoted. Dagmar and Karin exchange another little look, pleased wi Margo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny Palm Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church is filled with palms and lilies. Reverend Bock passes out palms to the children and people who file down aisle.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR
dialogues.text: “O'er all the way green palms and blossoms gay/Are strewn this day in festal preparation/Where Jesus comes to wipe our tears away/E’en now the throng to welcome him prepare...Hosanna... Even though she knows they’re not there, MARGO checks the for Lars and Bianca, but there’s only space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lars continues his vigil with Bianca. Karin knocks softly opens the door, Gus behind her.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: I have spring fever, we're going out to the lake. Wanna come? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 95.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She’s so weak. I think she’s in pain but she won't admit it.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: She wants to get out for a little while, Lars. cus Come with us. Do everybody good.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Bianca, don't you want to see this glorious day?

dialogues.speaker: -- LATER
dialogues.text: Gus, Karin, Lars and Bianca on the shore of the lake. The check the threat. sky--a northern spring sky, part promise, part

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Is that a storm over there?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: The weather said no.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Looks like a storm to me.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Honey, I need to stretch my legs, Maybe it’ll blow over. Let’s take a chance. Gus Lars?

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: You go. Bianca wants to stay and look at the water. Gus We won’t be far.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Holler if you need us.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Let’s not worry any more. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 96.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gus and Karin walk off hand in hand. Lars watches them go fondly. He likes watching them together. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: SAME, A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: Lars sits next to Bianca in her wheelchair. They watch th water. He speaks from the bottom of his heart.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: We still have so much to talk about. Everything is different because of you. I thought that we'd have years and years. He takes her hand, kisses her palm. LARS (CONT’D) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus looks at the sky again, Karin looks toward the lake.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: See? I was right. Here it comes. Karin starts moving back toward the lake, not sure of wha she sees.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Gus...

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: We'll just about make it home before-- Karin starts running.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Gus! At the edge of the lake, we can see Bianca’s wheelchair w it's rolled into the water. GUS immediately understands.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (already moving, to Karin) You okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: by Nancy Oliver - 97.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Go! Go! Gus sprints past her toward Lars who holds Bianca in his arms, a strange reverse pieta. Even in a long shot, we ca sense the intensity of Lars's grief. Bianca is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funeral on a beautiful, sunny spring day. Around the gr people stand or sit in folding chairs. No one wears black Almost everyone we've seen is present except children. La sits with Karin, Gus and Dagmar. He has just finished a crying spasm, is distant and quiet for the moment, in the space between waves of grief. The mourners are a little restless, unsure of how to behave at such a curious occas

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK
dialogues.text: Lars asked us not to wear black today. He did that to remind us that this is no ordinary funeral. Oh, no. Instead he would like us to join together in celebration of Bianca’s extraordinary life. @ The mourners settle, interested.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Without even trying, Bianca brought to this town the warmth, the laughter, the vivid color of her native tropics. She was a listener and a teacher. She was a lesson in courage and constancy. Did you ever once see her yield to disability or despair? People shake their heads, no, they never did. Everyone is moved in their own way. REVEREND BOCK (CONT’D) There is not one among us who could match her work ethic or her serenity in the face of illness and even death. The word touches them all and makes it real.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From her wheelchair, Bianca touched all of us in ways we could never e have predicted. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 98.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The mourners agree, this is very true.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND BOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And she left us with glowing memories of her generosity, her delightful company and her love of humanity. Oh, yes. We can be sure Bianca loved us all. Especially Lars. Everyone becomes aware of him. They watch him, compassion REVEREND BOCK (CONT’D) ESPECIALLY him. But Lars, don’t forget, she was first and foremost a missionary. A servant of God. Lars nods. He won't forget.

dialogues.speaker: REV. BOCK
dialogues.text: So let us not grieve for her. Let us not suffer. Let us rejoice. Bianca has not gone, she has gone AHEAD, where we all must go one day. And she will be there to greet us on that day, when we too return to our true home, safe forever in the bosom of the Lord. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: PEOPLE
dialogues.text: Amen. He begins to recite the Twenty-Third Psalm. Everyone know the words, some say it along with him.

dialogues.speaker: REV. BOCK
dialogues.text: “The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, He leadeth me beside still waters, he restoreth my soul...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The service is over, people disperse, talking. Gus and Ka talk to various configurations of friends and neighbors. Dagmar watches Lars as he accepts condolences, hugs, shak hands, reaches out. Margo, too watches Lars from a distan

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Come back to the house. Please. Bring the kids. We‘d love to have you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finally decided. Paul Lars if it’s a boy and Elinor Bianca if it’s a girl. It's clear that everybody will gather at the Lindstrom ho cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Gus approaches Dagmar. They look at Lars.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Can Lars drive with you? We have to be home when people start showing up and I don’t want to rush him...

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: of course. cus What comes next?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: @ As usual, I have no idea. They marvel at the strange and wonderful person Lars is.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He‘s--unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: The most creative, resourceful--and he’s strong, Gus, he's really strong. cus I never knew. I never knew him. Gus is full of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say. How to thank you. Without you...I mean, he’s my brother... He can’t find the words.

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: e It's a privilege. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 100.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Karin motions to him from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN
dialogues.text: Gus! Gus See you at the house?

dialogues.speaker: DAGMAR
dialogues.text: I'll be there. He hugs her warmly, he goes. Dagmar stays in the backgrou watching, as people leave. She is amused and moved by the whole experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cemetery is empty except for Lars, Margo and Dagmar, stand quite apart from one another. Margo and Lars are unaware of Dagmar. Lars looks at the headstones, his moth his father and “Bianca, Beloved Friend.” Dagmar starts to him, but from another direction, Margo joins Lars at the grave. Dagmar stops and watches.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: We used to come here sometimes. She liked it, even in winter,

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: I like it, too. Peaceful. They stand together looking at Bianca's grave. Dagmar wat the simple scene. We can hear birds.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: She asked me to let go, she said she was ready. She told me not to be sad. But I can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Me, neither.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: We'll feel better as time goes on. That’s what people say.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: It's true, I think, in a way. But there‘1l never be anyone like her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 101.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: Never. They stand for a few more moments, remembering Bianca. Th Lars wipes his eyes, looks around at the day and takes a breath. Dagmar smiles and walks away, leaving them alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: (doesn’t really want to) I guess we should catch up with everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: LARS
dialogues.text: (doesn’t really want to) In a while. You wanna take a walk?

dialogues.speaker: MARGO
dialogues.text: Yes. They wander off into the sunlight together. (CONT'D) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARS by Nancy Oliver - 102.
